III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Title Sufficiency of staff.
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty
to perform the prescribed functions required by these
administrative rules and in the agency's program statement
and to provide for the continual needs, protection, and
supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff 1 was not aware of Youth A's mental health needs, resulting
in poor supervision and an escalated incident that occurred on
04/20/2025.
Investigation Staff 1 was interviewed over the phone on 05/06/2025. She
reported she no longer worked for the facility. She recalled the
incident in question. She heard Youth A had AWOL’ed from the
facility and went in a facility car to attempt to follow her down the
street. Staff 1 believed she had two other youth with her at the
time but could not recall who they were. Staff 1 recalled
encountering Youth A a few miles from the facility, and she was
able to convince Youth A to get in the car with her. Youth A sat in
the back seat. Staff 1 recalled Youth A immediately talking about
wanting to get back out of the car. As Staff 1 pulled into a parking
lot, Youth A stated she could see police officers some distance
away and that she wanted to get out to talk to them. Staff 1
recalled Youth A opening the car door before she was able to stop
the car. She believed they were close to idling speed in the
parking lot when this occurred. Staff 1 believed Youth A landed
on her knees when she got out of the car. She recalled seeing
Youth A get up and walk over to where the police officers were
located. Staff 1 did not believe Youth A was limping or hurt after
getting out of the moving car. Staff 1 parked the car and
approached Youth A, who at that time was speaking with the
police officers. She tried to engage Youth A, but Youth A did not
speak back to her. Staff 1 recalled standing by as Youth A
escalated further, with the situation ending with law enforcement
deciding to transport Youth A to the hospital for evaluation. Staff 1
left the scene as this occurred and returned to the facility. She
recalled being informed Youth A was ready to be discharged later
in the evening, and she returned to pick up Youth A. Youth A was
2

then transported back to the facility without incident. Staff 1 did
not know how Youth A was able to get out of the moving
vehicle. She knew it was a newer vehicle but did not understand
how the child lock was not enabled, allowing Youth A to open the
car door from the back seat. Staff 1 noted she had been aware of
safety plans for Youth A, and that this situation did not involve any
planning that had previously been provided to staff. She also
recalled law enforcement asking her about any safety plans that
involved Youth A.
Police Officer 1 was interviewed over the phone on
05/06/2025. He recalled being with another police officer
performing a routine traffic stop when he was approached by
Youth A. This was after he witnessed Youth A get out of a moving
vehicle in a nearby parking lot. The police officer believed the car
that Youth A had been in was moving no more than five miles per
hour, but it was not parked. Youth A quickly came up to him and
he turned his attention to her. He recalled Youth A stating that
she was suicidal and that she was not going back to the
facility. The police officer recalled seeing Staff 1 approach them,
and he asked what her involvement was. Staff 1 told him she had
been trying to prevent Youth A from AWOL’ing from the
facility. The police officer noted Staff 1 never lost line of sight of
Youth A. He recalled not having any concern with Staff 1’s
involvement, noting that she was speaking about safety plans that
had involved Youth A. The police officer recalled Staff 1 not being
able to participate much in the conversation with Youth A as it
went on because her behavior escalated, and he made the
decision to transport her to the hospital for further evaluation.
Youth A’s Foster Care worker was contacted on
05/08/2025. She reported being aware of the incident in question
and not having any concerns with the care and supervision
provided by the facility. She noted the facility had been active in
safety planning for Youth A.
Youth A was interviewed over the phone on 05/08/2025. She
reported she had AWOL’ed from the facility and had intended on
going to the local police station. Staff 1 drove up to her and Youth
A agreed to get in the car with Staff 1. Youth A could not recall
why she got in the car willingly, remembering that it may have
been because Staff 1 stated they were not going to go back to the
facility. Youth A could not recall if anyone else was in the
car. After a short drive Youth A recalled seeing police officers
nearby. She immediately opened the rear passenger side door
and jumped out of the vehicle. Youth A recalled Staff 1 stating
3

“What are you doing?” Youth A didn’t remember falling when she
got out of the car. She also was not sure if it was moving or
parked. Youth A recalled Staff 1 following her up to the police
officers that she wanted to speak to, but did not recall if Staff 1
stayed with her as she spoke to them. Youth A confirmed she
went to the hospital with law enforcement, and Staff 1 came later
to pick her up.
Youth B and Youth C were interviewed over the phone on
05/08/2025. They confirmed they were not with Staff 1 or Youth A
during the original incident, but came with Staff 1 later in the
evening to pick Youth A up from the hospital. Both Youth B and
Youth C did not recall any concerns with the transportation of
Youth A back to the facility.
Documentation reviewed:
• Incident Report documentation dated 04/20/2025 was
provided and reviewed. The details in this incident report
were consistent with interviews provided for this
investigation.
• Facility policy titled “Transportation” and last dated
01/20/2021 was provided and reviewed. This policy and
procedure provided guidelines specific to the safety and
security of vehicles and the transportation of youth. The
policy does not specifically require any checking of child-
locks on facility vehicles.
• Safety Plan documentation regarding Youth A was
provided and reviewed. The most recent safety plan for
Youth A prior to the incident was dated 04/09/2025. It was
confirmed this had been received and signed by Staff
1. There were no specific requirements in this safety plan
that had not been followed by Staff 1 during the incident in
question.
o Daily Safety Plan Review Log documentation was
provided, with signatures from Staff 1 dating back to
the beginning of March 2025.
• Personnel file documentation for Staff 1 was provided and
reviewed. She had been hired on 11/04/2024 and received
orientation and training as required. No instances of
discipline were noted.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as per youth and staff
interviews and documentation reviewed Staff 1 was aware of
Youth A’s safety plans and triggers and provided adequate
supervision and engagement during the incident that occurred on
04/20/2025.
4

Consultation:
Consultation was provided regarding safety checks on vehicles,
including ensuring child locks are activated prior to use.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
